intro: Coronopus vulgaris, commonly known as the common crownflower, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in meadows and along roadsides. Its flowers bloom from June to August, and it is known for its aromatic, spicy scent. The plant has been used historically in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
